meanings.def: having a larger distance between opposite sides or surfaces than other similar objects or than normal
examples: a thick slice of bread
a thick book (= one that has a lot of pages)
a thick coat (= one made of heavy cloth)
thick fingers
Everything was covered with a thick layer of dust.
Use fairly thick wads of newspaper.
He wore thick glasses.
a thick carpet of snow

meanings.def: used to ask about or state the distance between opposite sides or surfaces
examples: How thick are the walls?
They're two feet thick.
The silk thread is only slightly thicker than a hair.

meanings.def: growing closely together in large amounts or numbers
examples: thick dark hair
This breed of cattle has a very thick coat.
His eyebrows were thick and bushy.
a thick forest
a screen of trees thick enough to conceal the building entirely
She padded noiselessly across the thick carpet (= that has a large number of fibres pressed closely together).

meanings.def: not flowing very easily
examples: thick soup
The effect will be ruined if the paint is too thick.
I was buried up to my waist in thick mud, unable to move.

meanings.def: difficult to see through; difficult to breathe in
examples: The plane crashed in thick fog.
Thick black smoke rose over the city.
Thick cloud covered the sky.
The air had grown thick and smoky.
thick with something The air was thick with dust.
(figurative) The atmosphere was thick with tension.

meanings.def: having a large number of people or a large amount of something in one place
examples: The beach was thick with sunbathers.

meanings.def: slow to learn or understand things
examples: Are you thick, or what?
I think some of them are basically just thick.
I'm not completely thick, you know.
If you weren't so thick you'd have spotted them coming!
She's not as thick as she looks!

meanings.def: easily recognized as being from a particular country or area
examples: a thick Brooklyn accent

meanings.def: deep and not as clear as normal, especially because of illness or emotion
examples: His voice was thick with emotion.

meanings.def: very friendly with somebody, especially in a way that makes other people suspect that something wrong, illegal or dishonest is involved in the situation
examples: You seem to be very thick with the boss!

meanings.def: family relationships are stronger than any others
to hit somebody/be hit on the head as a punishment
examples: You’ll get a thick ear if you’re not careful!

meanings.def: very friendly, especially in a way that makes other people suspect that something wrong, illegal or dishonest is involved in the situation
very stupid
a physical condition in which your head is painful or you cannot think clearly as a result of an illness or of drinking too much alcohol
examples: You’re going to have a thick head in the morning!

meanings.def: used to show that you are annoyed that somebody does not understand something
examples: When will you get it into your thick head that I don't want to see you again!

meanings.def: if people or things are thick/thin on the ground, there are a lot/not many of them in a place
examples: Customers are thin on the ground at this time of year.
Security officers were thick on the ground during the King’s visit.

meanings.def: the ability to accept criticism, offensive remarks, etc. without becoming upset

meanings.def: involved in the busiest or most active part of something
examples: As a player, he’s always in the thick of the action.
Her comments landed her in the thick of a family feud.

meanings.def: even when there are problems or difficulties
examples: He's supported the team for over ten years through thick and thin.
In marriage, you have to stick together through thick and thin.

meanings.def: in a way that produces a wide piece or deep layer of something
examples: Make sure you cut the bread nice and thick.

meanings.def: to talk about somebody/something in a way that makes them or it seem much better or much worse than they really are; to exaggerate something
examples: Praise them when necessary, but don't lay it on too thick.

meanings.def: quickly and in large quantities
examples: Questions were coming at them thick and fast.
